Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Bagpipe band at the Warner Hollywood Theatre for the premiere of The Hasty Heart
Description.caption: Handwritten in blue ink text from back of photograph: MPS - 659|~|Stamped in purple ink text from back of photograph: [Encircled illegible text in what appears to be a postal date stamp]|~|Taped-on paper with typed text from the back of photograph: With all the trappings and fanfare of the most important formal Hollywood opening in recent years, "The Hasty Heart," Warner Bros. film starring Ronald Reagan, Patricia Neal and Richard Todd, made its American screen debut before a distinguished audience comprised of a record number of film celebrities and civic dignitaries. Joining the Hollywood personalities and Los Angeles City officials, representatives of 36 foreign nations attended the gala premiere at the Warner Hollywood Theatre. In tribute to the Scottish hero of "The Hasty Heart," bagpipe music was provided for the festive occasion by the Pipers Band of Scottish Post No. 80, Canadian Legion.|~|Stamped in black ink text from back of photograph: Theater Arts Library
Description.note: Signage above the theater box office includes photographic images of the three top-billed actors in the film, "The Hasty Heart": Ronald Reagan, Richard Todd and Patricia Neal.|~|A photograph of movie-goers at the box office on premiere night for the film, "The Hasty Heart," held at the Warner Hollywood Theater. The photograph also depicts an appearance by the Pipers Band of Scottish Post No. 80, Canadian Legion.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Audrey Totter in High Wall
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Fearful Moment.... is that of Audrey Totter in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's High Wall, when she learns that the man she loves in about to be trapped and shot down as a ruthless killer. Robert Taylor and Herbert Marshall also star in the exciting and unusual mystery story, directed by Curtis Bernhardt. Robert Lord produced.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Herbert Marshall, Moroni Olsen, and Warner Anderson in High Wall
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Trailing a Killer..... Herbert Marshall calls on the doctors of a mental hospital, Moroni Olsen, left, and Warner Anderson, on the trail of a supposed homicidal manias, in a scene of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's High Wall. RObert Taylor and Audrey Totter also star in the exciting and unusual mystery picture, director by Curtis Bernhardt. Robert Lord produced.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Robert Taylor fighting an unidentified cast member in High Wall
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Taylor In Action... It's Robert Taylor, making it rough for his foe in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's High Wall, exciting mystery drama in which the star appears as a supposed homicidal maniac, accused of killin[sic] his wife. It;s his second post-war picture, with Audrey Totter, Herbert Marshall and Dorothy Patrick joining him in the outstanding cast. Curtis Bernhardt directed, Robert Lord produced.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Robert Taylor in High Wall
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Hunted!!!.... and a dangerous figure is Robert Taylor, as a supposed homicidal maniac who escapes from a mental institution, in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's High Wall, exciting mystery drama. Audrey Totter, Herbert Marshall and Dorothy Patrick also are cast with the star in his second post-war picture. Curtis Bernhardt directed, Robert Lord produced.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Dorothy Patrick in High Wall
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Beautiful Victim... Victim of a suddenly striking killing in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's High Wall in lovely Dorothy Patrick, who joins stars Robert Taylor, Audrey Totter and Herbert Marshall in the exciting and unusual mystery story. Miss Patrick plays the ill-fated young wife of Taylor, making his second post-war film. Curtis Bernhardt directed, Robert Lord produced.

AltTitle.uniform: History Is Made At Night  (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: HISTORY IS MADE AT NIGHT
Description.caption: Handwritten in black ink text from back of photograph: 675|~|Pasted-on paper with typed text from back of photograph: WW-2600-99.  Complications!--Jean Arthur, as Irene Vail in Walter Wanger's "History is Made at Night", doesn't know when she enters the fashionable New York caf√© that the head waiter who will greet her is the romantic Parisian (Charles Boyer) with whom she's in love. Miss Arthur, shown in this scene with her jealous screen husband, Colin Clive (right), Dora Clement and Carey Harrison, is wearing a beaded style creation weighing thirty-five pounds. Frank Borzage directed this romantic comedy drama in which Boyer and Miss Arthur are co-starred.|~|Walter Wanger presents Charles Boyer and Jean Arthur in "History Is Made At Night" with Leo Carrillo, Colin Clive, and Ivan Lebedeff. Directed by Frank Borzage. Released through United Artists.|~|Stamped in black ink text from back of photograph: UCLAArts-SpecialCollections

AltTitle.uniform: History Is Made At Night  (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: HISTORY IS MADE AT NIGHT
Description.caption: Walter Wanger presents Charles Boyer and Jean Arthur in "History Is Made At Night" with Leo Carrillo, Colin Clive, and Ivan Lebedeff. Directed by Frank Borzage. Released through United Artists.|~|Stamped in black ink text from back of photograph: Theater Arts Library|~|Pasted-on paper with typed text from back of photograph: WW-2600-109. Love In An Ice-Box--Charles Boyer and Jean Arthur don't mind the temperature as they run their own in this scene from Walter Wanger's "History is Made at Night". Boyer plays Paul Dumond, romantic maitre d'hotel of fashionable Paris and New York cafes, and Miss Arthur is Irene Vail, who convinces him a Park Avenue girl can really love a head waiter. Frank Borzage directed.|~|Handwritten in pencil text from back of photograph: #4 (encircled)|~|Handwritten in blue ink text from back of photograph: MPS-675-W.W.2600-109

AltTitle.uniform: History Is Made At Night  (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: HISTORY IS MADE AT NIGHT
Description.caption: Walter Wanger presents Charles Boyer and Jean Arthur in "History Is Made At Night" with Leo Carrillo, Colin Clive, and Ivan Lebedeff. Directed by Frank Borzage. Released through United Artists.|~|Pasted-on paper with typed text from back of photograph: WW-2600-171.  Unmasked!--When Jean Arthur, as Irene Vail, leaves her millionaire husband and resumes her career as a mannequin under an assumed name, a detective hired by her ruthless mate finds her. This scene from Walter Wanger's History Is Made At Night shows Miss Arthur, Helene Millard as her employer, and Roger Gray as the detective. Frank Borzage directed the romantic comedy drama in which Miss Arthur and Charles Boyer are co-starred and Leo Carrillo, Colin Clive and other personalities play prominent roles.|~|Stamped in black ink text from back of photograph: UCLA - Arts S/CChester NelsonCollections|~|Handwritten in black ink text from back of photograph: MPS 675|~|Handwritten in black ink text from back of photograph: 37

Title: HITLER GANG, THE
Description.caption: Handwritten in black ink text from back of photograph: 679|~|Copyright 1944, Paramount Pictures, Inc. Permission granted for Newspaper and Magazine Reproduction. (Made in U.S.A.)|~|Typed text from back of photograph: Ex-Hoofer Plays Hitler-- One of the outstanding motion picture characterizations of 1944 was given by Robert Watson, the former song and dance vaudeville performer. He portrayed Adolf Hitler in Paramount's documentary feature, "The Hitler Gang"[underlined in handwritten blue ink], winning the plaudits of the critics and the fans for the remarkable verisimilitude of the Hollywood copy to the original Fuehrer. He was selected to portray Hitler after twenty other players, including several top-ranking stars, had been tested for "the most unpopular role of the year."|~|Stamped in black ink text from back of photograph: UCLAArts-SpecialCollections|~|Stamped in purple ink text from back of photograph: Photo ByA. Whitey Schafer|~|Typed text from back of photograph: Ex-Hoofer Plays Hitler-- One of the outstanding motion picture characterizations of 1944 was given by Robert Watson, the former song and dance vaudeville performer. He portrayed Adolf Hitler in Paramount's documentary feature, "The Hitler Gang"[encircled in handwritten blue ink]. winning the plaudits of the critics and the fans for the remarkable verisimilitude of the Hollywood copy to the original Fuehrer. He was selected to portray Hitler after twenty other players, including several top-ranking stars, had been tested for "the most unpopular role of the year."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Shirley Temple and Franchot Tone in a scene from Honeymoon
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Honeymoon, "Fall-Guy";... BOOM!! Physically incapable of speech, Tone's well aware, at this point, that our "little sweetheart" is a big girl now!! Exclusive in your city.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Shirley Temple and Franchot Tone in a scene from Honeymoon
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: "Fall-Guy", Shirley Temple has come a long way from the "Little Miss Marker" roles that endeared her to all. Her starring role in RKO Radio's "Honeymoon" includes, among other departures, this walloping scene with co-star Franchot Tone. Continuity Layout No. 1. It all starts when she thinks Mr. Tone is getting too friendly (in the story, of course)... Seems like Shirley's in love with co-star Guy Madison, a soldier who's let her in on the secrets of Judo. Exclusive in your city.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Florence Eldridge and Fredric March receive direction from Michael Gordon in An Act of Murder
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Hint on How to Spend 20th Wedding AnniversaryMovie star Fredric March and Mrs. March, (Florence Eldridge on stage and screen) know from actual experience how to bserve a 20th wedding anniversary. They've done it. But in a new movie in which they appear together, Universal-International's "An Act of Murder," they offer a suggestion which is both practical and amusing. For a pictorial sequence from which many a man and wife who take each other more-or-less for granted, see below:2 - Then the judge turns to observe his wife, who shows no disgust, but has grown wistful. (Figure in left foreground is Director Michael Gordon moving in to watch crucial moment of scene.)
Description.note: (From left) Director Michael Gordon (back to camera), stars Florence Eldridge, Fredric March, and two unidentified actors in "An Act of Murder."

Name.subject: Schweitzer, Albert, $d 1875-1965
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Albert Schweitzer and two boys in "Albert Schweitzer"
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: "Albert Schweitzer" - Dr. Albert Schweitzer on the edge of the Ogowe River, where his jungle hospital is situated. A scene from "Albert Schweitzer", the definitive film biography of the Novel Prize winner who has achieved world-renown as a philosopher, theologian, missionary, physician, organist and, above all, as a man who has devoted his life to serving his fellow men. The Eastmancolor picture, produced and directed by Jerome Hill and photographed by Erica Anderson, took five years to make. It was filmed in Dr. Schweitzer's childhood village, Gunsbach, France and in the hospital-village in Lambarene, French Equatorial Africa. Narration by Fredric March and Burgess Meredith. Original score by Alec Wilder.|~|Jerome Hill and Erica Anderson present "Albert Schweitzer" in Eastmancolor. Narrated by Fredric March and Burgess Meredith.

"A Man Called Peter" chares the bill.|~|Jerome Hill and Erica Anderson present "Albert Schweitzer" in Eastmancolor. Narrated by Fredric March and Burgess Meredith.

Description.note: George Sanders (top) and Anne Baxter in "All About Eve."

Name.actor: Baxter, Anne|~|Davis, Bette, $d 1908-1989|~|Merrill, Gary|~|Marlowe, Hugh, $d 1911-1982|~|Holm, Celeste, $d 1917-2012
Name.producer: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation|~|Zanuck, Darryl Francis, $d 1902-1979
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Anne Baxter, Gary Merrill, Celeste Holm, Bette Davis, and Hugh Marlowe in All About Eve
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:A Story in Stillsof theDarryl F. Zanuck Production"All About Eve"for20th Century-FoxEve Harrington (Anne Baxter), left, a star-struck theater fan, ingratiates herself with a famous Broadway actress, Margo Channing (Bette Davis), right. Brought to Margo's dressing room by Karen Richards (Celeste Holm), wife of playwright Lloyd Richards (Hugh Marlowe), she listens with wide-eyed interest as stage director Bill Sampson (Gary Merrill), Margo's sweetheart, tells Margo how beautiful she is and urges her to hurry with her dressing so she can see him off to Hollywood where he will direct a picture.
Description.note: (From left) Anne Baxter, Gary Merrill, Celeste Holm, Bette Davis, and Hugh Marlowe in "All About Eve."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Lloyd Gough in All My Sons
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Lloyd Gough, who made his film debut as the fight manager in "Body and Soul," plays the philosophic neighbor of Edward G. Robinson and Burt Lancaster in "All My Sons." The Universal-International film is adapted from the Broadway production which won the New York Critics' Circle award as the best drama of 1946-47.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Burt Lancaster and Louisa Horton in All My Sons

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Burt Lancaster and Louisa Horton in All My Sons
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Burt Lancaster, who had the sophisticated leading ladies Ava Gardner and Lizbeth Scott in previous pictures, is romantically teamed with Louisa Horton, the simple, sincere "type," in "All My Sons." Miss Horton, a stage actress, makes her screen debut in the Universal-International drama, adapted from the New York Critics' Circle prize play of last season. Lancaster, hitherto viewed in rugged action roles, enacts a retiring, quiet mannered ex-soldier in the new film.
Description.note: Burt Lancaster (top) and Louisa Horton in "All My Sons."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections

Miss Horton, a stage actress, makes her screen debut in the Universal-International drama, adapted from the New York Critics' Circle prize play of last season. Lancaster, hitherto viewed in dynamic action roles, enacts a retiring, quiet-mannered ex-soldier in the new film.
Description.note: Burt Lancaster (left) and Louisa Horton in "All My Sons."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron in An American in Paris
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: A romantic Paris setting provides the atmosphere for a love scene between Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "An American in Paris". With an all-Gershwin musical score, the Technicolor picture also headlined Oscar Levant, Georges Guetary and Nina Foch in its outstanding cast. Vincente Minnelli directed, Arthur Freed produced.Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's joyous musical extravaganza, "That's Entertainment, Part II", is an encore presentation of memorable moments from the great MGM musicals, comedies and dramas of the past, hosted this time by the two greatest dancing stars the screen has ever known, Gene Kelly and Fred Astaire, who introduce the many fabulous films and stars with songs, dances, and humorous anecdotes. Saul Chaplin and Dan Melnick produced "That's Entertainment, Part II" with Gene Kelly directing the many new sequences that feature Astaire and himself.
Description.note: Gene Kelly (left) and Leslie Caron in "An American in Paris."

Title: John Mills and Richard Attenborough in The Baby and the Battleship
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: John Mills and Richard Attenborough in a scene from "The Baby and the Battleship," photographed in Color on location in the Mediterranean, opening an Exclusive California engagement on Wednesday May 29th at the Four Stare Theatre.Starring John Mills, Richard Attenborough and Lisa Gastoni, this light-hearted spoof of traditional Naval dignity revolves around a hilarious shore leave of two soldiers who smuggle a six-month-old baby aboard their ship just before it steams out to sea for training.
Description.note: John Mills (left) and Richard Attenborough in "The Baby and the Battleship."

Title: Robert Walker, Robert Taylor, Kenneth Spencer, and Phillip Terry in Bataan
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: In Bataan's Field...Robert Walker says a brief prayer for a member of dommed Yank patrol killed in the Philippines as Robert Taylor, Kenneth Spencer and Phillip Terry watch. The scene is from "Bataan," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's wartime film epic. Cast also includes George Murphy, Thomas Mitchell, Lloyd Nolan, Desi Arnaz, Barry Nelson, and Tom Dugan. Tay Garnett directed. Irving Starr produced.
Description.note: (From left) Robert Walker, Robet Taylor, Kenneth Spencer, and Phillip Terry in "Bataan."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Gary Cooper, Ray Milland, William A. Wellman, Brian Donlevy and other cast and crew on the set of Beau Geste
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Wellman Stages A Mutiny - William A. Wellman, wearing the white sweater and the jaunty beret, prepares to shoot a vital scene for Paramount's "Beau Geste". Brian Donlevy, in the blue uniform coat sprinkled with medlas, forms Gary Cooper, right, and Ray Milland into a firing squad.
Description.note: (From left) Ray Milland (left center), Gary Cooper, William A. Wellman, Brian Donlevy (foreground, in blue uniform), and other cast and crew members on the set of "Beau Geste."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Brian Donlevy, Gary Cooper, Ray Milland, and other cast and crew on the set of Beau Geste.
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Mutiny Misfires - Lined up are a score of Foreign Legion mutineers, who are about to be shot, both with camera and bullets, for a vital scene in Paramount's "Beau Geste". Brian Donlevy, wearing the blue uniform jacket and carrying the pistol, forms Gary Cooper and Ray Milland into an unwilling firing squad.
Description.note: Brian Donlevy (center), Gary Cooper, Ray Milland, and other cast and crew members on the set of "Beau Geste."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Ray Milland and Susan Hayward in Beau Geste
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: An Orchid To You -- To most people an orchid is a rare flower found in the corsage of a fortuante lady, or a symbol of extravagance, but to Susan Hayward it is a simple, inexpensive hobby. While working in Paramount's "Beau Geste" with Gary Cooper, Ray and the screen's new find Robert Preston, the young actress played a scene with Ray Milland in which he presented her with an orchid corsage. Attracted by the beauty of the flower she went tot he hot-house which furnished the bloom to the studio and discovered taht she could raise orchids at home with a minimum of trouble and expense.No. 1. On the set of "Beau Geste, which William Wellman is directing for Paraoumnt, Ray Milland and Susan Hayward play a scene in which he gives her an orchid.
Description.note: Ray Milland (left) and Susan Hayward in "Beau Geste."

Title: Mario Siletti and Gene Kelly in The Black Hand
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: At the Point of a Knife: Isabella's little brother, Rudy, has been abducted by the Black Hand. Their price is the list Lorelli has mailed. Determined to win this time, Johnny goes to Danetta (Mario Silleti), whose son has once been kidnapped but returned unharmed when he paid up. He forces Danette to tell him that the member of the gang to whom he paid off was Pietro Riago, the wine merchant.
Description.note: Mario Siletti (left) and Gene Kelly in "The Black Hand."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Jane Wyman and Charles Laughton in The Blue Veil
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: First Job-Jane Wyman takes over the care of Charles Laughton's motherless son as her first job after losing her own child, a scene from "The Blue Veil," a Jerry Wald-Norman Krasna production for RKO Radio. The baby was played alternately by the McDonald twins, Charles and Patrick. Miss Wyman, Richard Carlson, Laughton, Joan Blondell and Don Taylor share top honors in the picture.
Description.note: Jane Wyman (left) and Charles Laughton in "The Blue Veil."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Natalie Wood, Lewis Martin, and other cast members in The Blue Veil
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Serious Moment-Natalie Wood receives the sacrament of confirmation at the hands of the archbishop, Lewis Martin, in this scene from "The Blue Veil," a Jerry Wald-Norman Krasna production for RKO Radio. Jane Wyman, Richard Carlson, Charles Laughton, Joan Blondell and Don Taylor are starred.
Description.note: Natalie Wood (foreground, right), Lewis Martin (right, back to camera) and other actors in "The Blue Veil."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Jane Wyman, Harry Strang and other cast members in The Blue Veil
Description.caption: Jane Wyman (center, foreground), Harry Strang (right of Wyman) and other cast members in "The Blue Veil."|~|Text from back of photograph: Near Tragedy--Her eyesight failing with advancing years, Jane Wyman almost walks into the path of an automobile in this scene from "The Blue Veil" in which she co-stars with Richard Carlson, Charles Laughton, Joan Blondell and Don Taylor. The film is a Jerry Wald-Norman Krasna production for RKO Radio.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Jane Wyman and Richard Carlson in The Blue Veil
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Summer Romance-Jane Wyman and Richard Carlson find themselves hit hard by Cupid in this scene from "The Blue Veil," a Jerry Wald-Norman Krasna production for RKO Radio. Miss Wyman, Carlson, Charles Laughton, Joan Blondell and Don Taylor are co-stars.
Description.note: Jane Wyman (left) and Richard Carlson in "The Blue Veil."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Jane Wyman, Curtis Bernhardt, and Richard Carlson on the set of The Blue Veil

Miss Wyman, Carlson, Charles Laughton, Joan Blondell and Don Taylor are co-sttared.
Description.note: (From left) Jane Wyman, Curtis Bernhardt, and Richard Carlson on the set of "The Blue Veil."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Curtis Bernhardt, Jane Wyman, and Richard Carlson on the set of The Blue Veil
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Pleasant Reaction-Director Curt Bernhardt registers complete satisfaction as Jane Wyman and Richard Carlson rehearse a love scene for "The Blue Veil," a Jerry Wald-Norman Krasna production for RKO Radio. Starred in the film are Miss Wyman, Carlson, Charles Laughton, Joan Blondell and Don Taylor.
Description.note: (From left) Director Curtis Bernhardt, actors Jane Wyman and Richard Carlson on the set of "The Blue Veil."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Joan Blondell and Jane Wyman in The Blue Veil
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Relaxation-Joan Blondell reads a news item in a theatrical paper to Jane Wyman between shots of "The Blue Veil," a Jerry Wald-Norman Krasna production for RKO Radio in which both players are starred. Sharing the top spots with them in the film are Richard Carlson, Charles Laughton, and Don Taylor.
Description.note: Joan Blondell and Jane Wyman in "The Blue Veil."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Vivian Vance and Jane Wyman in The Blue Veil
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Ultimatum--Vivian Vance, just married to a widower with a child, tells Jane Wyman, the nurse who raised him, that she will no longer be needed. Scene from "The Blue Veil," a Jerry Wald-Norman Krasna production for RKO Radio. Miss Wyman, Richard Carlson, Charles Laughton, Joan Blondell and Don Taylor are co-starred.
Description.note: Vivian Vance (left) and Jane Wyman in "The Blue Veil."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Jane Wyman in The Blue Veil
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: It's Your Guess-Jane Wyman holds one of a pair of identical twins Brian and Brent Tobin, 14 months old, who alternate as Charles Laughton's son in "The Blue Veil," in which Miss Wyman, Richard Carlson, Laughton, Joan Blondell and Don Taylor are co-starred. Picture is a Jerry Wald-Norman Krasna production for RKO Radio.
Description.note: Jane Wyman (right) and either Brian or Brent Tobin in "The Blue Veil."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Agnes Moorehead and Richard Carlson in The Blue Veil
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Happy Meeting-Richard Carlson and Agnes Moorehead, friends of long standing, find themselves working together for the first time in years in "The Blue Veil," a Jerry Wald-Norman Krasna production for RKO Radio. Jane Wyman, Carlson, Charles Laughton, Joan Blondell and Don Taylor are starred.
Description.note: Agnes Moorehead (left) and Richard Carlson in "The Blue Veil."

Title: Jane Wyman and Curtis Bernhardt on the set of The Blue Veil

Description.note: Jane Wyman (left) and Curtis Bernhardt on the set of "The Blue Veil."

Jane Wyman heads a distinguished cast including Charles Laughton, Joan Blondell and Richard Carlson in the tender story of the life and loves of a pressional governess.
Description.note: Curtis Bernhardt (left) and Lewis Martin on the set of "The Blue Veil."

Title: Michel Ray in The Brave One

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Van Johnson and Gene Kelly in Brigadoon
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Look Who's Dancing!...It's Van Johnson, left, dancing alongside Gene Kelly for the first time in thirteen years as the two pair up in a comedy hoofing number of M-G-M's "Brigadoon". The last time they combined musical talents was in the 1941 hit, "Pal Joey" -- but there was one difference. Then, Johnson was just an unheralded dancer in the chorus and Kelly was the stage's newest star. Now, in the new Cinema-Scope musical, they're co-stars, along with Cyd Charisse, and Johnson is dancing for only the second time in pictures for the nostalgic reunion. Vincente Minnelli directs the new film, produced by Arthur Freed.
Description.note: Van Johnson (left) and Gene Kelly in "Brigadoon."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Robert Warwick, Charles Boyer and other cast members in a scene from The Buccaneer
Description.caption: "The Buccaneer"Produced by Henry Wilcoxon  Directed by Anthony Quinn  Supervised by Cecil B. DeMilleA Paramount Picture  In VistaVision  Color by Technicolor|~|Text from back of photograph: Pirates Meet in Prison -- Paramount's filmization of "The Buccaneer" includes many colorful and dramatic scenes, among which is a historical meeting in the New Orleans prison betewen Jean Lafitte, played by Yul Brynner, and Dominique You, portrayed by Charles Boyer. The action is a page lifted from history. Early in Janury, 1815, the pirate Lafitte bargained with General Andrew Jackson for the release of his buccaneers from prison in exchange fro badly-needed gunpowder and flint with which to halt the advence of British troops. Dominique You was Lafitte's "general" and, at the time of the imprisonment, Lafitte's men had lost faith in him. Lafitte takes the pardon papers to Dominique and then goes off to become a hero by fighting with Jackson. Dominique and the pirates also engaged in the Battle of New Orleans with Jackson and the enemy was routed. The picture also stars Charlton Heston, Claire Bloom, Inger Stevens, Henry Hull and E.G. Marshall. Henry Wilcoxon produced, Anthony Quinn directed and Cecil B. DeMille supervised. The picture was filmed in Technicolor and VistaVision.Dominique You (Charles Boyer), in what he believes is a farewell speech to fellow pirates, says, "There's only one thing we can trust in life -- and that is that it will end in death. When it comes, spit in its eye."
Description.note: Robert Warwick (left), Charles Boyer (center) and other cast members in a scene from "The Buccaneer."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Claire Bloom and Yul Brynner on the set of The Buccaneer
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Brynner Focuses on Bloom -- Yul Brynner, serving in two capacities, actor and photograph, ont he set of Paramount's "The Buccaneer," focuses on co-star Claire Bloom between Technicolor Vistavision filming of the adventure story. Brynner, an expert color photographer, has, in the past, sold many of his pictures to leading national U.S. magazines. He plays the title role in "The Buccaneer."
Description.note: Claire Bloom (left) and Yul Brynner on the set of "The Buccaneer."

Description.note: Yul Brynner (left) and Mickey Finn on the set of "The Buccaneer."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Mickey Finn, Yul Brynner, Charles Boyer, and other cast members in The Buccaneer
Description.caption: "The Buccaneer"Produced by Henry Wilcoxon Directed by Anthony Quinn Supervised by Cecil B. DeMilleA Paramount Picture In VistaVision  Color by Technicolor|~|Text from back of photograph: The Battle of New Orleans -- On January 8, 1815 was fought one of the most famous battles in United States history. It ended the War of 1812. This battle is portrayed in Paramount's epic action picture, "The Buccaneer," a Techni-color and VistaVision multi-million dollar production which stars Yul Brynner, Charlton Heston, Claire Bloom, Charles Boyer, Inger Stevens and Henry Hill. Jackson, with a makeshift army of 3,200 men, was out-manned four to one when the fabulous pirate, Jean Lafitte, turned from outlaw to pirate when he rejected an offer to earn wealth and standing to fight for the British and chose to lead his band of pirates into battle with Jackson in return for only the right to be American citizens. He brought Jackson desperately needed kegs of powder and 7,500 rifle flintlocks. The battle was fought in a thick fog and the British made use of rockets which they fired from large tubes. The flaming, screaming rockets were mainly used to strike terror in the minds of Jackson's motley army. Brynner plays Lafitte; Heston plays Jackson in the film. Boyer portrays Dominique You, pirate, who became an artillery hero that day. When that battle was finished, the British losses included 858 killed, 2,468 wounded. Jackson counted his own losses: 8 killed, 14 wounded. The Paramount picture, "The Buccaneer," was produced by Henry Wilcoxon, directed by Anthony Quinn, supervisied by Cecil B. DeMille.From the thick swamps come a long line of pirates, bearing powder and weapons and led by Jean Lafitte (Yul Brynner) and Dominique You (Charles Boyer).
Description.note: Mickey Finn (left), Yul Brynner (left foreground), Charles Boyer (center foreground), and other cast members in "The Buccaneer."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Robert F. Simon and cast members in a scene from The Buccaneer
Description.caption: "The Buccaneer"Produced by Henry Wilcoxon  Directed by Anthony Quinn  Supervised by Cecil B. DeMilleA Paramount Picture  In VistaVision  Color by Technicolor|~|Text from back of photograph: The Battle of New Orleans -- On January 8, 1815 was fought one of the most famous battles in United States history. It ended the War of 1812. This battle is portrayed in Paramount's epic action picture, "The Buccaneer," a Techni-color and VistaVision multi-million dollar production which stars Yul Brynner, Charlton Heston, Claire Bloom, Charles Boyer, Inger Stevens and Henry Hill. Jackson, with a makeshift army of 3,200 men, was out-manned four to one when the fabulous pirate, Jean Lafitte, turned from outlaw to pirate when he rejected an offer to earn wealth and standing to fight for the British and chose to lead his band of pirates into battle with Jackson in return for only the right to be American citizens. He brought Jackson desperately needed kegs of powder and 7,500 rifle flintlocks. The battle was fought in a thick fog and the British made use of rockets which they fired from large tubes. The flaming, screaming rockets were mainly used to strike terror in the minds of Jackson's motley army. Brynner plays Lafitte; Heston plays Jackson in the film. Boyer portrays Dominique You, pirate, who became an artillery hero that day. When that battle was finished, the British losses included 858 killed, 2,468 wounded. Jackson counted his own losses: 8 killed, 14 wounded. The Paramount picture, "The Buccaneer," was produced by Henry Wilcoxon, directed by Anthony Quinn, supervisied by Cecil B. DeMille.Led by bagpipers and drums to throw fear into the Americans through the sound of the strange music, the Highland troops of the British move toward Jackson's lines.

Name.actor: Boyer, Charles, $d 1899-1978|~|De Corsia, Ted|~|Hinton, Ed, $d 1919-1958|~|Hartleben, Jerry
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Ted de Corsia, Edgar Hinton, Jerry Hartleben, and Charles Boyer in The Buccaneer
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: A Pirate's Trouble Homecoming -- A pirate's life is not always of the "yo, ho, ho and a bottle of rum" type, as one dramatic scene in Paramount's "The Buccaneer" plainly shows. In the story, based on the true life adventures of the fabulous pirate Jean Lafitte, the famous buccaneer has to put to sea in an attempt to prevent a renegade crew of his from attacking an American ship. He reaches the scene too late and is forced to hang the rebellious captain who has disobeyed his orders. Then comes the return to his headquarters at Barataria, one of the islands off the coast of New Orleans. Because the booty is the first ever taken from a United States vessel, he orders it stored away and not divided. Other pirate leaders of his are openly critical, especially when Lafitte brings back one survivor of the sunken ship, the cabin boy who could reveal the criminal story. And the daughter of the hanged pirate tries to kill Lafitte by hurling a knife at him. Thus is the homecoming of this pirate. Yul Brynner plays Lafitte and Claire Bloom the pirate girl. Other stars are Charlton Heston, Charles Boyer, Inger Stevens and Henry Hull. The picture, photographed in Technicolor and VistaVision, was produced by Henry Wilcoxon, directed by Anthony Quinn and supervised by Cecil B. DeMille.Dominique You (Charles Boyer) tells First Mate (Edward Hinton) and Rumbo (Ted de Corsia) that the pirate Brown left only Miggs (Jerry Hartleben), the cabin boy, as survivor from the sunken Corinthian.|~|"The Buccaneer"Produced by Henry Wilcoxon  Directed by Anthony Quinn  Supervised by Cecil B. DeMilleA Paramount Picture  In VistaVision  Color by Technicolor
Description.note: (From left) Ted de Corsia, Edgar Hinton, Jerry Hartleben, and Charles Boyer in "The Buccaneer."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Robert F. Simon and cast members in a scene from The Buccaneer
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Pirates Scuttle a Ship -- Among the colorfully spectacular scenes in "The Buccaneer," Paramount's multi-million dollar production in Technicolor and VistaVision, depicts a pirate ship attacking an American ship, seizing all cargo of value and then sinking the vessl with no lives saved. Paramount built the American ship, the Corinthian, then burned much of it, as the pirate ship lies alongside. Hollywood was combed for physically powerful actors to portray the pirates since the entire scene employed violent action, with leaps between the two ships and climbing of the rigging. This scuttling of an American ship by a rebellious group of pirates under the fabulous Jean Lafitte was taken from the real-life of the pirate chief, played by Yul Brynner. It was this one act that proved disastrous to Lafitte after he'd become an American hero by aiding General Andrew Jackson, portrayed by Charlton Heston, at the Battle of New Orleans. Starring with these two in the production are Claire Bloom, Charles Boyer, Inger Stevens and Henry Hull. The film was produced by Henry Wilcoxon, directed by Anthony Quinn and supervised by Cecil B. DeMille.|~|"The Buccaneer"Produced by Henry Wilcoxon  Directed by Anthony Quinn  Supervised by Cecil B. DeMilleA Paramount Picture  In VistaVision  Color by Technicolor
Description.note: Robert F. Simon (holding torch) and other cast members in a scene from The Buccaneer.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Inger Stevens and other cast members in The Buccaneer
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Pirate's Kingdom Destroyed -- A highlight of Paramount's "The Buccaneer" depicts a real-life dramatic episode from the colorful life of the fabluous pirate, Jean Lafitte, played in the production by Yul Brynner. Lafitte, a man without a country, had left his pirate stronghold of Barataria, in swamplands near New Orleans, to offer the services of hsi pirates in the fight against the invading British. He wants only the right to live under the American flag. He and one of his captains, played by George Mathews, are riding home in a parogue, when they find their little kingdom completely destroyed. Lafitte is sure than the British, whom he has been intending to double-cross, have done the job. But Claire Bloom, a pirate's daughter who has managed to hide out when all the pirates have either been captured or fled into the swamps, bitterly tells Lafitte that it was Americans who have betrayed Lafitte. In spite of this, Lafitte did in real life lead his pirates into battle to help General Andrew Jackson defeat the British at the Battle of New Orleans on January 8, 1815. Other stars in the picture are Charlton Heston, Charles Boyer, and Inger Stevens. The picture, filmed in Technicolor and VistaVision, was produced by Henry Wilcoxon, directed by Anthony Quinn and supervised by Cecil B. DeMille.Leading citizens of New Orleans attend the reception for General Andrew Jackson (Charlton Heston) in the home of Governor Claiborne (E.G. Marshall). Annette (Inger Stevens), the governor's daughter, sings a song for the general.|~|Copyright ¬© 1958 by Paramount Pictures Corporation. Permission granted for newspaper and magazine reproduction when credit given to Paramount Pictures Corporation. (Made in U.S.A.)"The Buccaneer"Produced by Henry Wilcoxon Directed by Anthony Quinn Supervised by Cecil B. DeMilleA Paramount Picture In VistaVision Color by Technicolor
Description.note: Inger Stevens (seated, at piano) and other cast members in a scene from "The Buccaneer."

Name.subject: Ayres, Lew, $d 1908-1996|~|Siodmak, Robert, $d 1900-1973
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Lew Ayres and Robert Siodmak in a publicity still for The Dark Mirror
Description.caption: (Text from back of photograph) They Deal in Psychology and SuspenseFour years ago, when Lew Ayres went into the service, Robert Siodmak was struggling to convince Hollywood that his direction had authority and distinction to rank with the best. Now, with Lew out of the service and cast in his first post-war role, the same Siodmak, who has proved his directorial talent with "The Spiral Staircase," "The Killers," etc., is Lew's director. They combine their talents in "The Dark Mirror," Universal-International production written and produced by Nunnally Johnson. Lew plays a psychiatrist-crime unraveller and is co-starred with Olivia De Havilland, who plays a dual role as twins, one a charming girl, the other a maniacal murder. Thomas Mitchell is co-starred.
Description.note: Lew Ayres (left) and Robert Siodmak in "The Dark Mirror."

Filmed in brilliant color by Technicolor, this action-packed story of legendary exploits of the famed frontiersman stars Fess Parker, Buddy Ebsen and Jeff York and is released by Buena Vista.|~|Walt Disney presents"Davy Crockett and the River Pirates"With Fess Parker, Buddy Ebsen and Jeff York
Description.note: Fess Parker (left) and Clem Bevans in "Davy Crockett and the River Pirates."

Schaefer & Son in 1948.|~|The original Danish title of the film "Day of Wrath" is "Vredens Dag". The film is also known by the title, "Dies Irae".

Lisbeth Movin as Anne."|~|The original Danish title of the film "Day of Wrath" is "Vredens Dag". The film is also known by the title, "Dies Irae".

Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: The biggest stars in Hollywood history -- and over 250 of them -- make their bow in Paramount's "Elephant Walk," which also teams Elizabeth Taylor, Dana Andrews and Peter Finch. The newcomers are pachyderms. They did everything from help build the sets, acting as beasts of burden, to playing the "heavies" in the adventure romance, stampeding and destroying on cue.4. The house afire and toppling, one animal puts some finishing destructive touches to the elegant furnishings.|~|"Elephant Walk" A Paramount Picture. Color by Technicolor.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Elizabeth Taylor in Elephant Walk
Description.caption: Elizabeth Taylor in Paramount Pictures.|~|Text from back of photograph: Elizabeth Taylor, who co-stars with Dana Andrews and Peter Finch in Paramount's "Elephant Walk," models this magnificent Edith Head evening gown. Miss Head was influenced by the locale of the film, and the gown is East Indian in treatment. It is white chiffon with a one-sided draped bodice like an East Indian Sari that flows into the draped, looped skirt. The loop is also one-sided in the skirt which gives a continuity of the flowing line. With it Miss Taylor wears a fabulously jeweled matching gold and pearl earrings and upper-arm bracelet are also from East India. Note that the bodice ends in a long, flowing scarf that also resembles the Sari.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Elizabeth Taylor in Elephant Walk
Description.caption: Elizabeth Taylor in Paramount Pictures|~|Text from back of photograph: The combination of Elizabeth Taylor and ice pink is breathtaking, as you will see in Paramount's "Elephant Walk," which co-stars Dana Andrews and Miss Taylor. Here she models an ice pink dinner dress made of silk linen designed by Edith Head. The bodice is draped and molded and has a halter neckline. The belt is narrow and embroidered in gold and pink pearls. The full skirt is over a pink gauze that resembles an East Indian Sari. Miss Head repeats the motif with a matching pink East Indian Sari stole. Miss Taylor also uses matching pink linen sandals.

Title: Charles Korvin and Ella Raines in a candid photo on the set of Enter Arsene Lupin
Description.caption: Printed in the United States of America-Copyright 1944, Universal Pictures Co., Inc.|~|Stamped and handwritten text in black ink on back of photograph:MPS - 998 - 1408 - P 10 Theater Arts Library|~|Pasted-on, typed text on back of photograph:   1408-P10    UniversalScreen actress Ella Raines and her leading man, George [sic] Korvin, in an informal moment between scenes of their picture "Enter Arsene Lupin." It is Korvin's first picture. He came to Hollywood from New York where, as Goza Korvin, he established himself as a star in "Dark Eyes" which ran for eleven months. Miss Raines, after a series of top roles in such pictures as "Corvette K-225," "Cry Havoc," "Hail the Conquering Hero," "Tall in the Saddle" and "The Phantom Lady," is considered one of the major feminine discoveries of the year.|~|On the back of photograph and in blue ink, 'George' in the typed caption, has been crossed out and a handwritten'Charles' has been written above it, correcting the typed mistake of 'George' for the name of actor Charles Korvin.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Roman Klosowski in a scene from Eve Wants to Sleep.
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Credit: Contemporary Polish Films -- A Series Program (UCLA) (Still from "Eve Wants to Sleep") Polish cinema is virtually unknown in the United States. Yet over the past year it has notably called attention to itself with films of unusual artistry that have received critical acclaim wherever shown, and won numerous festival awards. The distinction extends beyond dramatic films to those of documentary and experimental vein as well, and outstanding examples of these will be screened for the first time in Southern California at the special series arranged by the UCLA Committee on Fine Arts Productions in association with the Los Angeles Film Council. All films carry English subtitles. Dates for the series are May 10, 17, 24, and 31, 1959, at 8:00 p.m. in Royce Hall Auditorium on the UCLA campus. For tickets and further information, call the UCLA Extension Division Ticket Office, OR 3-0971 or BR 2-6161, Ext. 379.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Barbara Lass in Eve Wants to Sleep.
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Credit: Contemporary Polish Films -- A Series Program (UCLA). Barbara Kwiatokowska has the lead role in "Eve Wants to Sleep" a wild comedy satirizing Polish institutions. This feature by Tadeusz Chmielewski is included in the series on Contemporary Polish Films which begins May 10, in UCLA's Royce Hall Auditorium at 8:00 p.m. Many award winners from last year's Cannes, Venice, Brussels, Cork and San Sebastian Festivals are scheduled for screening, including films by Alexander Ford and Andrzej Munk. All films carry English subtitles. For tickets and further information, call the UCLA Extension Division Ticket Office, GR 3-0971 or BR 2-6161, Ext. 379.

AltTitle.uniform: Every Girl Should Be Married  (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Alan Mowbray and Betsy Drake in Every Girl Should Be Married
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: What's going on? Betsy Drake's gesticulations seem to displease Alan Mowbray in "Every Girl Should Be Married," RKO Radio's lively comedy-romance about a small town girl with ring-fever who goes to the big city in search of matrimony, which stars Cary Grant, Franchot Tone, and Diana Lynn, and introduces Miss Drake to the screen.

AltTitle.uniform: Every Girl Should Be Married  (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Betsy Drake and Diana Lynn in Every Girl Should Be Married
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Plans - Betsy Drake (left) outlines her method of pursuing a husband to Diana Lynn in this scene from RKO Radio's "Every Girl Should Be Married," a lively comedy about a country girl with ring fever who goes to the big city in search of matrimony. Cary Grant, Franchot Tone and Diana Lynn are co-starred in the film, which introduces Miss Drake to screen audiences in the feminine lead.

AltTitle.uniform: Every Girl Should Be Married  (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Betsy Drake and Diana Lynn in Every Girl Should Be Married
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Prospective homemaker. Betsy Drake tells Diana Lynn about her ambition to become a homemaker in "Every Girl Should Be Married," RKO Radio's lively comedy-romance about a small town girl with ring-fever who goes to the big city in search of matrimony. Starred are Cary Grant, Franchot Tone and Diana Lynn, and Miss Drake is introduced to the screen.

From left to right - Victor McLaglen, William Frawley, Nan Grey, Tom Brown, Constance Moore and Donald Briggs." This caption can be found mistakenly attached to the back of the photograph with Item Ark #21198/zz00282sc3.

Title: Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and Henry Daniell in The Exile

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and Rita Corday in The Exile
Description.caption: [cont.] Realizing he needs a new hideout, Charles disguises himself in peasant garb and sets out. Seeing Katie poling her barge along the canal, he nimbly jumps from a bridge into the boat and goes with her.|~|Text from back of photograph: The Exile introduces Douglas Fairbanks Jr. as a producer-star, exactly 30 years (1917) after Doug Sr. began producing his own films. Produced by The Fairbanks Company, Inc., for Universal-International release, the film co-stars Doug Jr. with Maria Montez and introduces Paule Croset (pronounced Paul Crozay). Leading roles are played by Henry Daniell, Nigel Bruce and Robert Coote. Directed by Max Opuls, The Exile is a romantic action melodrama based on the historic escapades of Charles II of England. Full of sword-fighting, chases, battle scenes and love-making, it is the kind of film ideally suited to the Fairbankses[sic], father and son.
Description.note: From left to right: Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and Rita Corday (Paule Croset).

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Douglas Fairbanks Jr. in The Exile
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Look Out Below: Douglas Fairbanks lights[sic] on a table after doing a nine-foot drop to elude pursuers in his new picture, The Exile at Universal-International. Doug then jumps off the table and overturns it to block his enemies.

Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: You're late...Spencer Tracy takes Douglas Spencer to task for being late to his daughter's wedding rehearsal while Melville Cooper, the rector, and members of the bridal party including Charlie Smith, Carleton Carpenter, Don Anderson, Peter Thompson and Lucille Barnes listen in. The scene is from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's delightful comedy "Father Of the Bride" starring Tracy, Joan Bennett and Elizabeth Taylor. It was directed by Vincente Minnelli and produced by Pandro S. Borman. 1484-73.

Title: Spencer Tracy and Joan Bennett in The Father Of the Bride.
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: "What does the groom's family give--just the groom?" asks Spencer Tracy of screen wife Joan Bennett when the two arrange for the wedding reception of their daughter. This laugh-provoking scene is from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's delightful comedy, "Father of the Bride," starring Tracy, Miss Bennett and Elizabeth Taylor. It was directed by Vincente Minnelli and produced by Pandro S. Berman.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Spencer Tracy and Donald Clark in Father's Little Dividend
Description.caption: "Father's Little Dividend"A Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Picture|~|Handwritten in pencil and black ink text from back of photograph: MPS-1151|~|Typed text from back of photograph:Story In Pictures"Father's Little Dividend"...The Banks family is back again -- and with a dividend. Stars Spencer Tracy, Joan Bennett, Elizabeth Taylor and Don Taylor, Billie Burke and Moroni Olsen are once again united as a family ready to welcome the baby -- six-months-old Donald Clark. the director-producer tam of Vincente Minnelli and Pandro S. Berman are also back to bring the successor to 1950's comedy hit, "Father of the Bride" to the screen for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The screen play is once again by Albert Hackett and Frances Goodrich.9. Then comes the problem of granddad and the baby. They don't click. Whenever the youngster sees grandpa -- he screams.1519-31

Title: James Griffith, Wallace Ford, Felicia Farr, and Joel McCrea in The First Texan
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Scene from The First Texan, starring Joel McCrea in the title role as colorful Sam Houston. From left to right are James Griffith, Wallace Ford, Felicia Farr and Joel McCrea. The adventure spectacle was filmed in CinemaScope and Technicolor and produced for Allied Artists by Walter Mirisch.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Unidentified cast members in an action scene from The First Texan
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: An action scene in the stirring and spectacular picturization[sic] of the long, hard, and bitter struggle of the Texans for freedom from Mexico, The First Texan, which stars Joel McCrea in the title role. Filmed in CinemaScope and Technicolor, the outdoor adventure co-stars Felicia Farr and Jeff Morrow, and was produced by Walter Mirisch for Allied Artists.

Title: Eddie Bracken, William Holden, Dorothy Lamour and cast members in The Fleet's In
Description.caption: Handwritten in pencil text from back of photograph: Bracken|~|Handwritten in black ink text from back of photograph: MPS 1144|~|"The Fleet's In" starring Dorothy Lamour, William Holden, Eddie Bracken, with Betty Hutton, Betty Jane Rhodes, Leif Erickson and Jimmy Dorsey and His Orchestra featuring Bob Eberly and Helen O'Connell.- Directed by Victor Shertzinger -A Paramount Picture
Description.note: A majority of the cast appear in this publicity photograph from the film, "The Fleet's In": (l to r) Jimmie Dundee, Harry Barris, Boyd 'Red' Morgan, Rod Cameron, Dave Willock, Eddie Bracken, Jack Chapin, William Holden and Dorothy Lamour.|~|Director/composer Victor Schertzinger died on October 26, 1941, three days before the end of the film's production. According to Hollywood Reporter news items, Ralph Murphy finished directing the film but declined screen credit "so that the film could stand as a monument to a fine musical talent." Actress Dorothy Lamour stated in her autobiography that assistant director Hal Walker finished directing the film, but no contemporary information has been found to confirm this.

Name.actor: Lamour, Dorothy, 1914-|~|Lamarr, Hedy, $d 1913-2000|~|Cameron, Rod, $d 1910-1983|~|Bagley, Sam|~|Lamb, Gil, $d 1904-1995|~|Chapin, Jack

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Dorothy Lamour, Gil Lamb, Jack Chapin and cast members in The Fleet's In
Description.caption: Pasted-on paper with typed text attached to back of photograph: Revised Hornpipe --Dorothy Lamour is making a picture for Paramount called "The Fleet's In," so it is only natural that a quartet of sailors should help her to knock out a fast hornpipe. It's stepped up to Jimmy Dorsey's music with the help of (left to right) Gil Lamb, Jack Chapin, Sam Bagley and Rod Cameron.|~|Stamped and handwritten in black ink text from back of photograph:Theater Arts LibraryMPS-1144|~|Stamped in purple ink text from back of photograph: Credit Will Be AppreciatedParamount Photo ByC. Kenneth Lobben
Description.note: Director/composer Victor Schertzinger died on October 26, 1941, three days before the end of the film's production. According to Hollywood Reporter news items, Ralph Murphy finished directing the film but declined screen credit "so that the film could stand as a monument to a fine musical talent." Actress Dorothy Lamour stated in her autobiography that assistant director Hal Walker finished directing the film, but no contemporary information has been found to confirm this.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Betty Field and Robert Cummings in Flesh and Fantasy.
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: New romantic team is starred. Providing a romantic note for Universal's "Flesh and Fantasy" are Betty Field and Robert Cummings, who are co-starred in one of the three episodes of the film. The picture, which has Charles Boyer and Julien Duvivier as co-producers, stars Boyer and Barbara Stanwyck in one episode and Edward G. Robinson with Anna Lee and Thomas Mitchell in the third. Duvivier directed as well as co-produced the film.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Betty Field with makeup artist Jack Pierce on the set of Flesh and Fantasy.
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: From: Universal Studios - Universal City, Calif. Returning to the screen after a long absence (during which she became a mother) Betty Field will be seen in the Charles Boyer-Julien Duvivier episodic film, "For All We Know," wearing a mask which is the counterpart of her real face. Universal makeup chief, Jack Pierce, is shown studying her facial contours in preparatory to making the mask, which is essential to the story telling of an ugly-duckling who, Cinderella-like, is transforming by her love for a man into a beautiful girl. "For All We Know" is an all-star production in which Edw. G. Robinson, Tom Mitchell, Barbara Stanwyck, Dame May Whitty, Gloria Jean, Alan Curtis, Boyer himself, Grace McDonald and others appear.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Betty Field and Robert Cummings in Flesh and Fantasy.
Description.caption: "Flesh and Fantasy" starring in order of their appearance, Robert Benchley, Betty Field, Robert Cummings, Edward G. Title: Baseball pitchers Bill McAfee and Malcom Moss with actress Thelma Todd from Follow Thru
Description.caption: Stamped and handwritten in black ink from back of photograph: Theater Arts LibraryMPS - 1163|~|Pasted-on paper with typed text from back of photograph: They Know About Curves---Bill McAfee and Malcolm Moss, youthful pitchers with the Chicago Cubs, meet Thelma Todd, when they visit the Paramount studios where Miss Todd is playing the role of a golf champion in "Follow Thru". McAfee got a try-out this season with the Cubs after having pitched at the University of Michigan. Moss was a Vanderbilt College chucker who has been with Louisville in the American Association and was purchased by Chicago this year. Moss was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary scholastic society, at Vanderbilt and is a graduate in law from the University of Chicago.|~|Handwritten in pencil text from back of photograph: Bill McAfee & Malcolm Moss pitchers with Chicago Cubs meet Thelma Todd

AltTitle.uniform: For whom the bell tolls (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Director Sam Wood and his Technicolor camera crew at work on the set of For Whom The Bell Tolls.
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Hollywood's Most Difficult Location; 6. A director's eye view. Shooting a panoramic shot, with a sheer drop of 3,780 feet hanging beneath him, Director Sam Wood and his Technicolor camera crew line up for the next sequence. Workers had to be lashed to their camera when the winds reached 75 miles per hour speed. The temperature often dropped to ten degrees below zero.

Description.caption: Pasted-on paper with typed text from back of photograph: Babies steal the situation right away from the stars on the Four Wives set at Warner Bros. Even Director Michael Curtiz tries to curry favor with one of the infant members of his cast. Priscilla (hidden from view by Curtiz, Lola and Rosemary Lane and Gale Page are holding the infants who bring the third generation of the Lemp family to the screen in the picture. May Robson is adding her bit to the administration society.|~|Stamped in black ink text from back of photograph: Photography By Madison LacyWarner Bros. License To Reproduce With Copyright Notice Granted Newspapers, Magazines And Other Periodicals|~|Stamped and handwritten in black ink and pencil text from back of photograph:Theater Arts LibraryMPS-1158

AltTitle.uniform: Francis Goes To West Point  (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Donald O'Connor, Alice Kelley, Francis the Talking Mule, Lori Nelson and William Reynolds in Francis Goes to West Point
Description.caption: Pasted-on paper with typed text from back of photograph: From: U-I Universal City, Calif.Francis Gives Commands in "Francis Goes To West Point"Donald O'Connor, Alice Kelley, Lori Nelson and William Reynolds snap to attention as Francis, the talking mule, gives the commands in Universal- International's "Francis Goes to West Point." This is the third comedy in the popular talking mule series and shows Donald receiving an appointment to West Point when he frustrates an attempt by saboteurs to destroy an atom plant. Francis joins O'Connor at West Point as mascot for the Army football team.[this text has been typed twice in order to be displayed on both sides when paper attachment is folded over edge of photo]|~|Printed in U.S.A. - ¬© 1952, Universal Pictures Company, Inc. - Permission granted for newspaper and magazine reproduction - Any other use, including television, prohibited
Description.note: Francis the Talking Mule was voiced by actor Chill Wills.

AltTitle.uniform: Francis Goes To West Point  (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Lori Nelson and William Reynolds in Francis Goes to West Point
Description.caption: Pasted-on paper with typed text from back of photograph: From: U-I, Universal City, Calif."Francis Goes To West Point" - - A Pictorial SynopsisStarring Donald O'Connor and his famous talking mule pal, this is the third of the comedy series which has proved a box-office bonanza. Emphasizing youth in its cast and telling a story placing the mule in a likely and natural setting, it is the best of the series. Featured roles go to young U-I discoveries, Lori Nelson, Alice Kelley, Palmer Lee, Williams [sic] Reynolds. Screenplay is by Oscar Brodney, direction by Arthur Lubin, production by Leonard Goldstein for Universal-International. The story in pictures:6. But Van Allen is in love with Barbara Atwood (Lori Nelson), which Cynthia Daniels has sensed with feminine intuition. And Cynthia also has been attracted by Peter Stirling, who, in his troubles, has paraded the carpet before the Colonel's desk. (1689-21)[this last paragraph of text has been typed twice, in order to be displayed on both sides when paper attachment is folded over edge of photo]|~|Printed in U.S.A. - ¬© 1952, Universal Pictures Company, Inc. - Permission granted for newspaper and magazine reproduction - Any other use, including television, prohibited

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Jesse White and Victoria Horne in a scene from Harvey
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: From: Universal-International, Universal City, Calif."Harvey"--- A Pictorial Synopsis"Harvey" is the movie presentation of Mary Chase's Pulitzer Prize play of 1945 - the award "which was won by a hare." The play about an invisible rabbit who, oddly enough, was viewed by theatregoers on Broadway for more than four years, is the most expensive dramatic property ever to reach the screen, topping "Life with Father" in its cost of a million dollars plus profit percentage for movie rights. It is presented with the same spirit and characterization which made it unforgettable theatre. Starring JAMES STEWART who twice replaced Frank Fay in the original company, featuring JOSEPHINE HULL, pixie personality of the stage (familiar in movies from "Arsenic and Old Lace") and introducing JESSE WHITE of the stage company, the cast will command consideration at Academy Award time. Directed by Henry Koster, "Harvey" was produced by John Beck for Universal-International. The story in pictures:6. Wilson goes to the Dowd residence, doesn't find Elwood, but discovers lonesone Myrtle Mae - and her romantic life gets a big lift. Wilson goes for her and her onion sandwiches! Veta escapes Chumley's Rest in the confusion, calls her lawyer, Judge Gaffney, and orders him to sue Dr. Chumley for holding her on what she considers must be at least a white slavery charge.

Their appearance in the final film has not been confirmed."

Description.note: A candid photograph taken on the set of the film, "The Hitch-Hiker," featuring (l to r): an unidentified man in straw hat (but, quite possibly, Collier Young, the producer and co-writer of the film, as well as the ex-husband of Ida Lupino. Young is also listed as portraying an uncredited, Mexican peasant in the film), Ida Lupino (director/co-writer of the film), Frank Lovejoy, Edmond O'Brien, William Talman and an unidentified woman (behind Talman).

Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: 5. In Walter Wanger's Superscope production for Allied Artists, "Invasion Of The Body Snatchers," starring Kevin McCarthy and Dana Wynter, directed by Don Siegel, Larry Gates, Kenneth Patterson, King Donovan and Kevin McCarthy try to solve the mystery of the terror that has siezed [sic: seized] their town.

Title: Kevin McCarthy in The Invasion of the Body Snatchers
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: 5 (86)That night Miles tries an experiment, searching, he finds many pods and injects them with poisons of various kinds. None is effective. Now almost the entire population of Santa Mira has been hit by the seizure, which is spreading to other towns.

The Universal-International picture, eighth in the series of popular comedies celebrating the exploits of the Kettles, co-stars Marjorie Main and Arthur Hunnicutt.

Title: Stewart Granger, Deborah Kerr, Richard Carlson, and Cast Members in King Solomon's Mines
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Seeking Information... Deborah Kerr, Stewart Granger, in charge of the safari, (gun on shoulder) and Richard Carlson, MIss Kerr's film brother, seek information from the natives in this scene of Metro Goldwyn Mayer's King Solomon's Mines. The trio search for Miss Kerr's husband missing from a previous trek across the Dark Continent. The Technicolor film was directed by Compton Bennett and Andrew Martin[sic], and was produced by Sam Zimbalist.

AltTitle.uniform: No Room For The Groom  (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Piper Laurie, Tony Curtis, Spring Byington, and Don Defore in No Room for the Groom
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: No Room for the Groom--- A Pictorial Synopsis, No Room for the Groom is that most timely of comedies, a story of young lovers whose attempts at lawful marriage are baffled by the draft law and a mother-in-law. Starring Tony Curtis and Piper Laurie with Don DeFore and Spring Byington, it was written for the screen by Joseph Hoffman, directed by Douglas Sirk and produced by Ted Richmond for Universal-International. The story in pictures: 10. But Lee beats Alvah to his compartment, where he finds her with the champagne and saturated with heady perfume. Looking out the window they see mother wilting in defeat on the shoulder of would-be son-in-law, who still has his cement factory even if he hasn't cemented family relations.

AltTitle.uniform: One Of Our Dinosaurs Is Missing  (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Peter Ustinov and other unidentified cast members steal a dinosaur in One of Our Dinosaurs Is Missing
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: How to Steal a Dinosaur... Scenes from Walt Disney Productions', One of Our Dinosaurs Is Missing, a rollicking rave to find hidden microfilm on a museum dinosaur, show (top pictures) how to get rid of pesky museum guards. The next step (bottom left) is to secure ropes and tarpaulins and pull the bony beast from its moorings. Final step (bottom right) is to load the artifact onto a flatbed steam truck as Hnup Wan (Peter Ustinov), foreground, oversees the caper.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Eve Arden, Olga San Juan, and Ava Gardner in One Touch Of Venus
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:From: Universal-InternationalUniversal City, Calif."ONE TOUCH OF VENUS" - - - A Pictorial Synopsis"One Touch of Venus" does more than successfully bring a hit musical show to the screen; it gives Ava Gardner what might well be called her showiest role in films. She plays Venus - and how! It also gives Robert Walker the top light comedy role of his career. Dick Haymes is their co-star, with Olga San Juan and Eve Arden featured. The film is produced by Lester Cowan for Universal-International release, with the show's original music by Kurt Weill and lyrics by Ogden Nash and Ann Ronnell. Wm. A. Seiter Directed. The story in pictures:7. When Gloria does meet Venus, the latter is under the wing of Mollie (EVE ARDEN), sharp-tongued secretary to Mr. Savory, who has ordered the new mannequin given "the works" to beautify her. Gloria and Mollie are, of course, amazed at how little they can do to improve upon Venus.7. When Gloria does meet Venus, the latter is under the wing of Mollie (EVE ARDEN), sharp-tongued secretary to Mr. Savory, who has ordered the new mannequin given "the works" to beautify her. Gloria and Mollie are, of course, amazed at how little they can do to improve upon Venus.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Robert Duvall in The Outfit
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:MGM EDITOR'S PORTFOLIO...."THE OUTFIT" presented by MGM stars Robert Duvall, Karen Black, Joe Don Baker and Robert Ryan in a hard-hitting story of a man just out of prison, intent on avenging his brother's murder by the syndicate. Filmed on location in and around Los Angeles, "THE OUTFIT" was produced by Carter De Haven and directed by John Flynn who wrote the screenplay based on Richard Stark's novel. Jerry Fielding composed and conducted the musical score.CAPTIONS:1920-1Robert Duvall stars in MGM's "THE OUTFIT" as a man who dares take on an entire crime syndicate in seeking to avenge his brother's death.1920-2Joanna Cassidy makes her screen debut in MGM's "THE OUTFIT" in the role of a beautiful woman married to a crime boss played by Robert Ryan.1920-3Joe Don Baker stars with Robert Duvall in MGM's "THE OUTFIT", the story of a two-man war against the crime syndicate.1920-4In MGM's "THE OUTFIT", Karen Black stars as the girl friend of a man who dares take on a crime syndicate to avenge his brother's murder.1920-5Robert Duvall and Karen Black star as two people in love, bucking a crime syndicate in MGM's "THE OUTFIT".1920-6Robert Duvall (left) and Joe Don Baker (right) shoot it out with professional killers in MGM's "THE OUTFIT".1920-7Richard Jaeckel and Sheree North co-star as pawns of a crime syndicate in MGM's hard-hitting film "THE OUTFIT".1920-8Robert Ryan portrays the head of a crime syndicate and Joanna Cassidy his wife in MGM's "THE OUTFIT".1920-9Robert Duvall battles-to-the-death with a mob leader (Timothy Carey) in MGM's "THE OUTFIT".

Title: Lillian Cornell in The Quarterback
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:ON HER HIGH HORSE--Displaying her ability to ride this Arabian steed is Lillian Cornell, of Paramount's "The Quarterback," at the stables of Robert Young, also of the film. Miss Cornell, who was brought to Hollywood from Chicago radio, has had several singing roles, including the recent football comedy part with Wayne Morris, but is practicing horseback tricks--just in case she is cast in an equestrian epic.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Richard Morris and Wayne Morris in The Quarterback
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:GETS BROTHER START - having achieved film fame himself, Wayne Morris now is encouraging his young brother, Richard, who has acting aspirations. The elder Morris now is starred in a twin role in Paramount's "The Quarterback," with Virginia Dale and Lillian Cornell. Richard, just out of high school, weighs as much as his brother--a good 200 pounds, and also likes all kinds of athletes. The two are great pals despite a five-year difference in ages. Acting is a new line in the Morris family, the boys' parents being non-professionals.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections

Title: Mexican Indian in director Sergei Eisenstein's Thunder Over Mexico
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:"THUNDER OVER MEXICO"The genius of Sergei M. Eisenstein is manifest many times in "Thunder Over Mexico." In this scene the great Russian places an Indian of today closely resembling the Indian ancestor carved in stone centuries ago in the pyramids of Teotihuacan.
