Title: Director Sergei Eisenstein on the set of his film "Thunder Over Mexico"
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:"THUNDER OVER MEXICO"The Russian Director Sergei M. Eisenstein and G. V. Alexandrov, during the filming of "Thunder Over Mexico." In the background the ruins of the Temple of the Warriors (El Templo de los Guerreros) at Chichen Itz'a in Yucatan.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Director Sergei Eisenstein on the set of his film Thunder Over Mexico
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:"THUNDER OVER MEXICO"Sergei M. Eisenstein and his camera man, Eduard Tisse, as dusk comes over Mexico. In the background, "The Castle" pyraminds [sp] among the ruins of Chichen Itz'a. Taken during the filming of "Thunder Over Mexico."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Mexican Indian woman in Sergei Eisenstein's Thunder Over Mexico
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:"THUNDER OVER MEXICO"Types of Mexican Indian women chosen by Sergei M. Eisenstein to enact various roles in his film, "Thunder Over Mexico."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Celebration in Sergei Eisenstein's Thunder Over Mexico
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:Still from Eisenstein's "Viva Mexico"

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Martin Hernandez in Sergei Eisenstein's Thunder Over Mexico
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:"THUNDER OVER MEXICO"Sebastian and the bull of the Corpus Christi celebration in "Thunder Over Mexico" directed by Sergei M. Eisenstein.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Maguey (agave) gardener in a camera study for Sergei Eisenstein's Thunder Over Mexico
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:"THUNDER OVER MEXICO"A camera study made by Eduard Tisse for a scene in "Thunder Over Mexico" directed by Sergei M. Eisenstein. This is the maguey gatherer, drawing from the heart of the great plant the syrup-like substance from which the Mexicans make their favorite drink, pulque.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Mexican Indians self-flagelating in Sergei Eisenstein's Thunder Over Mexico
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:"THUNDER OVER MEXICO"Self flagellation of the Mexican Indians at Easter time plays a part in the Sergei M. Eisenstein film "Thunder Over Mexico." These Indians carrying across their bare flesh limbs of giant cacti the thorns and spines of which pierce their flesh. It is a penance for their sins during the year.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Mexican woman with a dead body in Sergei Eisenstein's Thunder Over Mexico
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:"THUNDER OVER MEXICO"After the 'punishment of the horses' come little Maria, the sad faces Madonna of "Thunder Over Mexico" What was to be a day of great happiness, her wedding day - is one of death and tragedy. A scen from the ...Eisenstein film.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Martin Hernandez in Sergei Eisenstein's Thunder Over Mexico
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:"THUNDER OVER MEXICO"'Sebastian' the leading character in "Thunder Over Mexico" directed by Sergei M. Eisenstein, is played by a Mexican-Indian named Martin Hernandez, a native of Apam.NOTE: the figure of the bull which "Sebastian" carries is used by the natives during the celebration of the carnival during Corpus Christi.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Mayan castle in Sergei Eisenstein's Thunder Over Mexico
Description.caption: "THUNDER OVER MEXICO"A memory of early Mayan culture...the Cabrera castle in Chichen Itz'a in Yucatan. here Sergei Eisenstein made many of the sequences of "Thunder Over Mexico."

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Mexican Indian girl in Sergei Eisenstein's Thunder Over Mexico
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:"THUNDER OVER MEXICO"A Heroine Unsung...the little Madonna like girl child who plays the heroine in "Thunder Over Mexico" must remain unknown to the millions who will see her upon the screen. Report has it the girl came from a maguey plantation in the state of Hidalgo, however in the rush of Eisenstein's departure from the United States, much of the official record of the expedition was lost - the cast of the players has never been found.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Maxene Andrews and production crew members on the set of Road to Rio
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Last-minute makeup touches are given to Maxine[sic] of the harmonizing Andrew Sisters as she prepares to make her movie debut with Bing Crosby in Paramount's Road to Rio, which also stars Bob Hope and Dorothy Lamour.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Dorothy Lamour and Jimmy Durante in Road to Rio
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Jimmy Durante took his eyes off Dorothy Lamour long enough to admire her live-orchid hat at the gala preview of My Favorite Brunette, starring her and Bob Hope. That dress, by the way, is a preview in itself because Dorothy wears it in Road to Rio, in which she recently finished working with Hope and Bing Crosby.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Bob Hope, Bing Crosby, and extras in Road to Rio
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: 2. Bob makes like a flying gazelle (elephant, spelled backwards) as Bing starts to warm up.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Bob Hope, Bing Crosby, and extras in Road to Rio
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: An intricate Latin-American dance routine, combined with a little judo, some startling extemporaneous vocalizing by Bing Crosby and some expert juggling feats by Bob Hope, provides one of the most hilarious scenes the mirth-and-melody due ever has perpetrated in their frequent Road excursions for Paramount. The strenuous incident takes place in Road to Rio, fifth of the popular series, and finds Hope impersonating lovely Carmen Miranda, in a hefty sort of way.1. Bing and Bob start their preliminary skirmishing in a catch-as-catch-can samba. Hope is on the right, under the bowl of fruit. Bing in on the left, behind the moustache[sic].

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Bing Crosby and dancer John Skins Miller in Road to Rio
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: 3. Bing is a adept pupil and thoroughly masters the entire dance in very short order. Upon Miller's final OK, the entire sequence is recorded and filmed.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Maxene, Patty, and LaVerne Andrews in Road to Rio
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Although they have recorded a number of smash hits together, Paramount's Road to Rio marked the first time that the harmonizing Andrew Sisters have worked with Bing Crosby in a motion picture. The sisters, left to right, are Maxine[sic], Patty and LeVerne.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: The O'Moyne Family, cast members in a scene from Sally and Saint Anne
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: From: U-I, Universal City, Calif. "Sally and St. Anne"--- A Pictorial Synopsis"Sally and St. Anne" is a comedy that is both human and spiritual, hearty and soulful, dealing with the wonder workings of a faith as Irish as leprechauns. Starring Ann Blyth and Edmund Gwenn, it was written by James O'Hanlon and Herb Meadow, directed by Rudy Mat√© and produced by Leonard Goldstein for Universal-International. The story in pictures:3. Sally lives in a home that is humble, but honest, and subject to the elations and despair familiar to the Irish. Her brother Willie (Lamont Johnson) is an aspiring composer who can't compose. Brother Mike (Jack Kelly) is "The Great O'Moyne" who dreams of being a great magician. Brother Danny (Hugh O'Brian) is a fighter who gets knocked out every fight. Pop (Otto Hulett) and Mom (Frances Bavier) have their hands full keeping the kids on even keel - and making both ends meet.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Audrey Totter, Susan Hayward, Joseph Sistrom and Claude Binyon meet author Frederic Wakeman on the set of The Saxon Charm
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: From Universal-International, Universal City, Calif."Saxon Charm" Author Meets His Characters in PersonFrederic Wakeman, author of the best-sellers, "The Hucksters" and "The Saxon Charm," visited Universal-International Studio to see the latter novel come to life on the sound stages. Here he is (left) meeting Audrey Totter and Susan Hayward, with Producer Joseph Sistrom (sport coat) and scenarist-director Claude Binyon. Robert Montgomery and John Payne appear opposite Misses Totter and Hayward at the head of the film's cast.

Title: Robert Montgomery and Audrey Totter in a scene from The Saxon Charm
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: From: Universal-International, Universal City, Calif."The Saxon Charm" -- A pictorial SynopsisBased on the novel by Frederic Wakeman (author of "The Hucksters"). "The Saxon Charm" is the story of Matt Saxon, theatrical producer, a genius at producing enemies. Written as a screenplay by Claude Binyon, who also directed, the movie stars Robert Montgomery in the meatiest role of his recent career. The film was produced by Joseph Sistrom for Universal-International. The story in pictures:9. Also while Saxon is in Hollywood Alma receives a phone call from her agent, cancelling a contract which would have given her a chance in films - because of rumors Saxon spread about her in Hollywood. When he returns to N.Y., Alma is waiting for him to tell him what she thinks of him. As Alma walks out of his life, Saxon threatens to poison himself.

Title: Nat "King" Cole with songwriters Ray Evans and Jay Livingston between scenes in The Scarlet Hour
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Part of the plot of Paramount's "The Scarlet Hour" has the star of the picture, Carol Ohmart, dropping in at the Beverly Hill's Hotel to hear Nat "King" Cole sing a song. The tune, written especially for "The King" and the picture is "Never Let Me Go," which disc jockeys have already labeled a hit.1. Here Nat runs over the ditty with the boys who wrote it, Ray Evans, left, and Jay Livingston. This is the duo who won Academy Awards for "Buttons and Bows," and "Mona Lisa."(Please credit The Scarlet Hour)Still - 2/9

Title: Edward G. Robinson and director Fritz Lang betwen scenes on Scarlet Street
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: From Unviersal Studio, Universal City, Calif.;Edward G. Dresses Fit To KillYes, that's a kitchen apron - and yes, it's being put on Edward G. Robinson. That's Director Fritz Lang who's tieing the apron strings while the actor is preoccupied with the telephone. Motive bahind this odd situation is a sinister one. It's for a scene in "Scarlet Street" in which Edward G. wears the apron to play a henpecked husband who washes the dishes when his wife tells him to. But he does more than that; he murders - with an ice pick! "Scarlet Street" stars Robinson with Joan Bennett and Dan DUryea, memorable trio of "Woman in the Window" and is the creation of Diana Productions, organized by Director-producer Lang, Producer Walter Wanger, and Miss Bennett, (Mrs. Wanger). Their film will be released by Universal.

Title: Actors in a scene from The Searching Wind
Description.caption: Hal Wallis' Production "The Searching Wind" Starring Robert Young, Sylvia Sidney, Ann Richards with Dudley Digges and introducing Douglas Dick. Directed by William Dieterle. Director of Photography-Lee Garmes, A.S.C. Screenplay by Lilian Hellman. Based on the play by Lilian Hellman. A Paramount Picture.|~|Text from back of photograph: [From promotional material for film] Hal Wallis - the producer of 'Casablanca', 'Love Letters' and 'Saratoga Trunk' now brings you 'The Searching Wind', his most dramatic motion picture. What strange power could drive this man from the lips of the woman he married into the arms of the woman he loved? Robert Young. Sylvia Sidney. Ann Richards. "The Searching Wind", From the Successful Broadway Play by Lillian Hellman, America's Foremost Woman Dramatist, with Dudley Digges and introducing Douglas Dick. Directed by William Dieterle. Screenplay by Lilllian Hellman. A Hal Wallis Production. A Paramount Picture.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: George Nader and Jeanne Crain in The Second Greatest Sex
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: 1794-19AD, The Second Greatest Sex, Universal-International; Paired in Romantic Musical -- Jeanne Crain and George Nader share star honors as a pair of lovebirds in a war-beset Kansas town in Universal-International's "The Second Greatest Sex." Filmed in both CinemaScope and Technicolor, the rollicking musical of what "Lysistrata" did to a small Kansas town features an all-star cast headed by Miss Crain, Nader, Kitty Kallen, Bert Lahr, Keith Andes, Paul Gilbert, Mamie Van Doren and Tommy Rall.

Filmed in both CinemaScope and technicolor, the rollicking musical of what "Lysistrata" did to a small Kansas town features an all-star cast headed by Jeanne Crain, George Nader, Miss Kallen, Bert Lahr, Keith Andes, Paul Gilbert, Miss Van Doren and Tommy Rall.

Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: 1794-P43, The Second Greatest Sex, Universal-International; Strange Inhabitants -- Universal-International's famous Western Street is populated by women only for the first time in its spectacular screen career as it serves as a setting for U-I's "The Second Greatest Sex." Here, the CinemaScope camera moves in on a sequence involving Kitty Kallen, Jeanne Crain, Mamie Van Doren and others. Filmed in both CinemaScope and Technicolor, the rollicking musical of what "Lysistrata" did to a small Kansas town features an all-star cast headed by Miss Crain, George Nader, Miss Kallen, Bert Lahr, Keith Andes, Paul Gilbert, Miss Van Doren and Tommy Rall.

AltTitle.uniform: Secret Life Of Walter Mitty, The  (Motion picture)
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Danny Kaye and Virginia Mayo in a scene from The Secret Life of Walter Mitty
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: SG-2000 -- 260, 263, 265, 267, 274, 278; THROUGH STORM AND GALE -- Dauntless Walter Mitty (Danny Kaye) grasps the helm with confidence, and his sweetheart Virginia Mayo holds on with utmost faith in her hero. It seems as if Mitty is having another of his famous daydreams, and forgets that he is only an employee of a fantastic fiction magazine in Samuel Goldwyn's Technicolor comedy, "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty", directed by Norman Z. McLeod, co-starring Mr. Kaye and Miss Mayo, with Boris Karloff, Fay Bainter and Ann Rutherford, and based on the James Thurber story.

Name.actor: Kaye, Danny|~|Bates, Florence, $d 1888-1954|~|Jones, Gordon, $d 1912-1963|~|Rutherford, Ann, $d 1920-|~|Bainter, Fay, $d 1892-1968

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: The cast in a scene from The Secret Life of Walter Mitty
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: SG-2000-117; HOMELY SCENE... Danny Kaye, as Walter Mitty, the man who was immortalized by James Thurber in his famous short story, clutches his girl Ann Rutherford, as Gordon Jones gets prettied up by Florence Bates under the approving smile of Fay Bainter in Samual Goldwyn's Technicolor comedy, "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty," co-starring Mr. Kaye and lovely Virginia Mayo and his hilarious exploits with international criminals and beautiful heroines.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Barbara Hale, Anthony Quinn, Ralph Moody and extras in a scene from Seminole
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: From: U-I, Universal City, Calif.; "SEMINOLE" --- A Pictorial Synopsis."Seminole" is a story of Osceola, chief of the Seminoles, and of his tribe's historic struggle to retain their Everglades home. Starring ROCK HUDSON, BARBARA HALE, ANTHONY QUINN and RICHARD CARLSON, the screenplay is by Charles K. Peck, Jr., direction by Budd Boetticher, and production by Howard Christie for Universal-International. The story in pictures:3. Lance is ordered on patrol, with a sergeant assigned by Major Degan, the commanding officer, to spy on him because of his Seminole sympathies - and Revere slips away into the Everglades to visit the village of Osceola. She is led by Kulak (Ralph Moody), a sub-chief, and closely followed by his warrior son, Kajeck (Hugh O'Brian), as they seek out Osceola's refuge.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Gary Cooper and Joan Leslie in a scene from Sergeant York
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: When Warner Bros. planned the filming of Sergeant York, Gary Cooper was the only man in Hollywood deemed capable of authentically portraying Alvin C. York, the hero of World War I. After an extensive search for a leading lady to play the role of York's wife, the studio awarded the choice plum to newcomer Joan Leslie, recently elevated to stardom. Howard Hawks directs the film, with Walter Brennan, Margaret Wycherly, George Tobias and Dickie Moore prominent in the supporting cast.

Title: Walter Brennan and Gary Cooper in Sergeant York
Description.caption: Stamped in black ink text from back of photograph:UCLA Theatre Arts Library|~|Stamped in black ink text from back of photograph: Mac Julian  Warner Bros.License to reproduce with copyright notice granted newspapers, magazines and other periodicals.|~|Stamped in pink ink text from back of photograph: APR 22 1941Call-Bulletin Library|~|Handwritten in pencil text from back of photograph: Bob Thomas Coll.|~|Handwritten in blue ink text from back of photograph: Sergeant York|~|Stamped and handwritten in black ink text from back of photograph:Theater Arts LibraryMPS 948Sergeant York.|~|Handwritten in pencil text from back of photograph: Negative Available ASC 843|~|Pasted-on paper with typed text from back of photograph: When Warner Bros. cast Gary Cooper in the starring role in SERGEANT YORK, the studio astutely placed Walter Brennan in the role of Pastor Pile, who preaches pacifism to him. Brennan has always been a perfect foil for the screen acting of Cooper. He ably supported the lanky actor in "Meet John Doe" and "The Westerner," for which he won an Academy Award. Another interesting bit of casting was giving Joan Leslie, sensational young newcomer, the role of Alvin C. York's sweetheart in the film, which is directed by Howard Hawks.

Name.subject: Poitier, Sidney
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Sidney Poitier in The Slender Thread
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Trouble...As a Crisis Clinic worker, Sidney Poitier attempts to learn the identity of an anonymous caller in this scene from "The Slender Thread," a Paramount Picture which probes into the life of a woman who has become the object of a citywide search. Sidney Poitier, Anne Bancroft, Telly Savalas, and Steven Hill star in the suspense drama produced by Stephen Alexander and directed by Sydney Pollack from Stirling Silliphant's screenplay.

Name.subject: Savalas, Telly, $d 1924-1994
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Telly Savalas and wife at industry screening of The Slender Thread
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: A special invitational screening of Paramount's The Slender Thread for opinion-making groups representing all communication media and motion picture and television arts and sciences, was held on the evening of December 8th, 1965, at the Screen Director's Guild Theatre in Hollywood, as a major phase of a campaign to qualify the film for "Oscar" nominations. Mr. Howard W. Koch, Vice President in Charge of Production and Studio Operations, hosted a gala supper party which followed immediately after the screening. Among those in attendance were Stephen Alexander, Producer of The Slender Thread and Telly Savalas and Steven Hill, co-stars of the film, which was directed by Sydney Pollack, from an original screenplay by Stirling Silliphant.In this photo, left to right: Mr. and Mrs. Telly Savalas
Description.note: Telly Savalas (left) and wife at an industry screening of "The Slender Thread."

Mr. Howard W. Koch, Vice President in Charge of Production and Studio Operations, hosted a gala supper party which followed immediately after the screening. Among those in attendance were Stephen Alexander, Producer of The Slender Thread and Telly Savalas and Steven Hill, co-stars of the film, which was directed by Sydney Pollack, from an original screenplay by Stirling Silliphant.In this photo: Michel Thomas and Christine Schmidtmer -- the latter was one of the feminine leads in Hal Wallis' Boeing Boeing.

Title: Sidney Poitier, Indus Arthur, and Jason Wingreen in The Slender Thread
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: Edge of Defeat...Sidney Poitier, as a Crisis Clinic worker, fears he has lost touch with an anonymous caller while Indus Arthur and Jason Wingreen stand by in this scene from "The Slender Thread," a Paramount Picture, which probes into the life of a woman who has become the object of a citywide search. Sidney Poitier, Anne Bancroft, Telly Savalas and Steven Hill star in the suspense drama, produced by Stephen Alexander and directed by Sydney Pollack from Stirling Silliphant's screenplay.
Description.note: (From left) Sidney Poitier, Indus Arthur, and Jason Wingreen in "The Slender Thread."

Name.subject: Silliphant, Stirling, $d 1918-1996
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. Library. Performing Arts Special Collections
Title: Stirling Silliphant and wife at a screening of The Slender Thread
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph: A special invitational screening of Paramount's The Slender Thread for opinion-making groups representing all communication media and motion picture and television arts and sciences, was held on the evening of December 8, 1965, at the Screen Director's Guild Theatre in Hollywood, as a major phase of a campaign to qualify the film for "Oscar" nominations. Mr. Howard W. Koch, Vice President in Charge of Production and Studio Operations, hosted a gala supper party which followed immediately after the screening. Among those in attendance were Stephen Alexander, Producer of The Slender Thread and Telly Savalas and Steven Hill, co-stars of the film, which was directed by Sydney Pollack, from an original screenplay by Stirling Silliphant.In this photo: Mr. and Mrs. Stirling Silliphant

Title: Pat O'Brien and Broderick Crawford in Slightly Honorable
Description.caption: Text from back of photograph:Pat O'Brien and Broderick Crawford are "stopped" by the camera in this action picture of their vicious battle staged for a scene in Walter Wanger's "City for Sale". Director Tay Garnett spent three days photographing this punishing sequence and each man bore the burdens of the encounter for several days. Both O'Brien and Crawford were thoroughly beaten and shaken up while making the scene. Crawford almost knocked out himself when he missed a swing at O'Brien, slipped and cracked his head against a desk. In the picture, the pair are seen as law partners who set out to bare the graft in the state paving racket and become involved in two murders.
